questions.text: The Hb level in healthy woman has the mean 13.5g/dl and SD 1.5g/dl. What is the Z score for a woman with Hb 15g/dl?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Z-score is a standardized value that tells us how many standard deviations a given data point is from the mean. It is calculated using the formula:

Z = (X - μ)/ σ

Where:

  • X is the value we want to standardize (in this case, the Hb level of the woman, which is 15 g/dl),
  • μ is the mean of the population (13.5 g/dl), and
  • σ is the standard deviation of the population (1.5 g/dl).

Z = (15 - 13.5)/ 1.5 = 1.5/1.5 =1

So, the Z-score for a woman with an Hb level of 15 g/dl is 1.

Key Takeaway:

Z-score tells how many standard deviations a value is above or below the mean, and is calculated as:
Z = (X - Mean) / SD

questions.text: For a given set of values, Mean = 20, Median = 24, and Mode = 26. The given distribution is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A distribution is said to be left-skewed (negatively skewed) when:

  • Mean < Median < Mode

This indicates that the tail of the distribution extends to the left, pulling the mean lower than the median and mode.

In this case:

  • Mean = 20
  • Median = 24
  • Mode = 26

→ So, mean < median < mode, confirming left (negative) skewness.

Visual Aid:

Left-Skewed (Negatively Skewed) Curve

Explanation of other options:

Symmetric (Option A): Symmetric implies mean = median = mode

Right skewed (Option B): Would require mean > median

Either symmetric or skewed (Option D): Too vague; this dataset clearly shows skewness

Key Takeaway:

When mean < median < mode, the distribution is negatively skewed (left-skewed).

questions.text: State whether the data reflecting the age at death of individuals in the general population are likely to be skewed to the right, skewed to the left, or symmetrical:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Age at death is negatively (left) skewed because a majority of people die in old age, but a small number die prematurely, pulling the tail to the left.

  • Left-skewed distribution has a longer tail on the left (lower values) and most data clustered toward higher values.
  • Natural upper limit: Most deaths occur after a certain age (e.g., 60-80), and very few people die at extremely low ages in a general population.
  • Early mortality due to accidents, congenital disorders, or diseases occurs less frequently but affects the left side of the curve.
  • Therefore, the data is not symmetric and the mean < median < mode, characteristic of a left-skewed curve.

Explanation of other options:

Skewed to the right (Option A): Applies to data like income or housing prices, not applicable here.

Symmetrical (Option C): Would imply equal distribution around the mean, which is not true for age at death.

Key Takeaway:

In general population data, age at death follows a left-skewed distribution, with a long tail toward younger ages and clustering around older ages.

questions.text: Which of the following terms accurately describe the distribution shown in the figure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A distribution that shows a long tail towards higher values is:

  • Positively skewed (Option A):
    • The tail is stretched toward the right (higher values), with more data clustered on the lower side. The mean > median > mode.
  • Skewed to the right (Option B):
    • This is a synonymous term with "positively skewed." Both describe a distribution that has a long right tail.
  • Asymmetrical (Option C):
    • The curve is not mirror-image around the center. Skewed distributions are inherently asymmetrical.

Since all three terms correctly describe the same type of distribution shown in the figure, the correct answer is All of the above (Option D).

Key Takeaway:

A right-tailed distribution is positively skewed, skewed to the right, and asymmetrical-all of which apply.

questions.text: Which of the following are considered measures of spread?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Measures of spread (or dispersion) reflect how much the values in a dataset vary around the central tendency:

  • Interquartile Range (Option A):
    • Measures the range within the middle 50% of the data (between Q1 and Q3).
    • Less sensitive to outliers, making it useful in skewed distributions.
  • Range (Option B):
    • Simple difference between maximum and minimum values.
    • It reflects total spread but is highly affected by outliers.
  • Standard Deviation (Option C):
    • Quantifies average distance of data points from the mean.
    • A commonly used measure for normally distributed data.

Key Takeaway:

All three-range, interquartile range, and standard deviation-are recognized measures of spread in statistics.

questions.text: Pearson's skewness coefficient is given by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pearson's first coefficient of skewness quantifies the direction and magnitude of asymmetry in a distribution using:

Skewness = (Mean - Mode) / Standard Deviation

  • If Mean > Mode, the distribution is positively skewed
  • If Mean < Mode, the distribution is negatively skewed

This method is most appropriate for unimodal and roughly symmetric distributions.

Key Takeaway:

Pearson's first skewness coefficient = (Mean - Mode) / Standard Deviation; used to assess symmetry in data.

questions.text: Histogram is used as a method of presentation for:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Histograms are graphical representations primarily used for quantitative continuous data.

  • The x-axis shows continuous intervals (bins), and the y-axis shows frequency.
  • Unlike bar charts, the bars in a histogram touch each other, reflecting the continuity of the data.

They are ideal for:

  • Displaying the shape (e.g., normal, skewed) of data
  • Observing central tendency and dispersion
  • Identifying outliers or modes in continuous datasets

Explanation of other options:

Qualitative data (Option A): Presented using bar charts or pie charts, not histograms, because categories have no numerical scale.

Discrete data (Option C): While histograms can be adapted for discrete data, bar charts are typically preferred since the values are countable and not continuous.

Nominal data (Option D): Also qualitative, with no inherent order - best displayed using bar or pie charts, not histograms.

Key Takeaway:

Histograms are best used to represent the frequency distribution of continuous quantitative data.

questions.text: If each value of a given group of observations is multiplied by 10, what will be the standard deviation of the resulting dataset?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

When every observation in a dataset is multiplied by a constant (k):

  • The mean becomes μ′=kμ\mu' = k\muμ′=kμ
  • The standard deviation becomes σ′=kσ\sigma' = k\sigmaσ′=kσ

Thus, multiplying all values by 10 will result in:

  • New standard deviation = 10 × original SD

This is because standard deviation is a measure of spread, and stretching the data by a constant factor stretches the spread by the same factor.

Related Important Points:

Key Takeaway:

When a dataset is multiplied by a constant, the standard deviation is scaled by the same constant.

choices.text: Since both mean and standard deviation are equal it should be a symmetric distribution
The distribution is likely to be positively skewed
The distribution is likely to be negatively skewed

questions.text: The distribution of random blood glucose measurements from 50 first-year medical students was found to have a mean of 3.0 mmol/litre with a standard deviation of 3.0 mmol/litre. Which of the following is a correct statement about the shape of distribution of random blood glucose in these first-year medical students?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Knowing only the mean and standard deviation is insufficient to determine the shape of a distribution. These two parameters provide information about the central tendency and spread of the data, but not about skewness or symmetry.

  • A mean = standard deviation does not imply symmetry or any specific skew.
  • The shape of the distribution (normal, skewed, bimodal, etc.) depends on higher-order moments like skewness and kurtosis, which are not given in this scenario.

Explanation of other options:

Since both mean and standard deviation are equal it should be a symmetric distribution (Option A) : Equal mean and SD doesn't confirm symmetry; it's not a mathematical criterion.

The distribution is likely to be positively skewed (Option B): In a positively skewed distribution, the mean is usually greater than the median-not always equal to SD.

The distribution is likely to be negatively skewed (Option C): In a negatively skewed distribution, the mean is typically less than the median-not linked to SD.

Key Takeaway:

Without skewness or data visualization, the shape of a distribution cannot be inferred solely from mean and SD.

questions.text: In a normal distribution, how much of the sample is included within 1.95 standard deviations of the mean?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

According to the Empirical Rule (68-95-99.7 rule):

  • Approximately 68% of values lie within ±1 SD
  • Approximately 95% of values lie within ±2 SD
  • Approximately 7% of values lie within ±3 SD

Since 1.95 SD is very close to 2 SD, the percentage of the data included is approximately 95%.

This rule applies only to normal distributions, and is used to interpret Z scores and confidence intervals.

Key Takeaway:

In a normal distribution, 95% of the values lie within ±1.95 to ±2 SD from the mean.

questions.text: Mean haemoglobin of a group of pregnant females is found to be 10.6 gm/dl with standard deviation of 2 gm/dl. 5% pregnant females in this group will have their hemoglobin below
questions.solution:
Explanation:

To find the haemoglobin level below which 5% of pregnant females in this group will have their haemoglobin, we need to use the concept of z-scores and the standard normal distribution.

Given:

  • Mean (μ) = 10.6 gm/dl
  • Standard deviation (σ) = 2 gm/dl
  • Desired percentile = 5%

We will first find the z-score corresponding to the 5th percentile using the standard normal distribution table or a calculator:

z=Inverse Normal CDF (0.05)

Once we have the z-score, we can use it to find the corresponding haemoglobin level (x) using the formula:

Z = (X - μ)/ σ

X = (Z * σ) + μ

z=Inverse Normal CDF (0.05)

z ≈ -1.645

X = (-1.645 * 2) + 10.6 =

X ≈ -3.29 + 10.6

X ≈ 7.31 gm/d

So, the haemoglobin level below which 5% of pregnant females in this group will have their haemoglobin is approximately 7.31 gm/dl.

questions.text: An obstetrician used the APGAR score to assess the health of 30 newborn infants. The results showed most of them with scores >7. What is the correct interpretation of the data distribution?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

When the majority of data points are clustered toward the higher end of a scale (e.g., scores >7 in this case), the distribution has a longer tail on the left side. This is known as a negatively skewed distribution.

  • The APGAR score ranges from 0 to 10.
  • Scores >7 are considered normal and healthy, so if most newborns score >7, the bulk of the data is on the right side.
  • Therefore, the tail (i.e., fewer values) would be on the left, which defines negative skewness.
  • The peak is on the right (scores >7).
  • The left tail is longer, indicating negative skew.

Explanation of other options:

Data is symmetrical (Option A): Symmetry implies equal distribution around the center. Since most scores are high (>7), the distribution is skewed, not symmetrical.

Data is positively skewed (Option C) : Positive skew has a long right tail and concentration of values on the left. This is opposite to the scenario.

Data is symmetrically skewed (Option D) : No such statistical term exists. Skewness is directional - either positive or negative.

Key Takeaway:

If most values in a dataset are high, the distribution will have a negative skew (tail on the left).
